message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate extravasation of the drug from the peripheral intravenous line, which can cause tissue injury. Phentolamine is an alpha-blocker that can prevent further tissue injury by reducing vasoconstriction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest extravasation, which occurs when a drug escapes from a blood vessel and enters surrounding tissue. Phentolamine is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that can reverse the vasoconstriction and prevent further tissue injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the drug caused vasoconstriction, leading to tissue ischemia and necrosis. Phentolamine is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist used to treat vasospasm and prevent tissue injury. Procaine is not indicated in this case, and Conivaptan and Heparin have no direct effect on arteriolar smooth muscle cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug mentioned in the question is likely a vasodilator, and the patient’s symptoms suggest extravasation of the drug into the surrounding tissues. Phentolamine is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that can reverse the vasoconstrictive effects of the drug and prevent further tissue injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient is experiencing extravasation, which is the leaking of drug solution out of the vein and into the surrounding tissue, leading to tissue injury. The drug works by increasing inositol trisphosphate concentrations in arteriolar smooth muscle cells, so phentolamine is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent further tissue injury by reversing the vasoconstriction caused by the drug. Procaine is a local anesthetic and not indicated in this situation. Conivaptan is a vasopressin antagonist and not indicated. Heparin is an anticoagulant and not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug administered likely caused ischemia and tissue injury at the IV site. Phentolamine can reverse the vasoconstrictive effects of the drug and prevent further tissue injury. Procaine is a local anesthetic, Conivaptan is used for hyponatremia, and Heparin is an anticoagulant, and none of them is indicated in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug administered is likely a vasopressor that caused vasoconstriction, leading to tissue injury around the IV site. Phentolamine can block the action of the vasopressor and prevent further tissue injury. Procaine is a local anesthetic and not appropriate for this situation. Conivaptan is a vasopressin antagonist and heparin is an anticoagulant, neither of which would be helpful in preventing further tissue injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug administered is likely to be a vasopressor, which caused vasoconstriction and tissue ischemia at the intravenous line site. Phentolamine is an alpha-blocker that can reverse vasoconstriction and prevent further tissue injury. Procaine is a local anesthetic and heparin is an anticoagulant, which are not appropriate for treating vasoconstriction. Conivaptan is a vasopressin antagonist, which is not indicated for this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest extravasation, meaning the medication leaked from the vein into surrounding tissue causing tissue death. Phentolamine is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that can dilate blood vessels and improve blood flow to the tissue, preventing further injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug administered is likely a vasopressor which constricts blood vessels, leading to tissue necrosis around the IV site. Phentolamine is a vasodilator and can reverse the effects of the vasopressor, preventing further tissue injury. The other options are not appropriate for this scenario.
